page.title: 01Llanfrechfa and Ponthir
page.content: The meaning of Llanfrechfa is uncertain. Llan means an enclosure usually reserved for the purposes of religion. The village of Ponthir lies between Cwmbran and Newport, and in 1677 was in the boundary of Usk. The language was Welsh, but today very few people speak welsh in our village. In 1605 the name of our village was Pontheere, at a leter peiod the final 'e' was taken off. Sometime later it was called Ponthir. When the raileay station was built in 1978 it gave its proper spelling of Ponthir, Ponthir meaning low bridge. It eventually took its name from the bridge over the river, the other name that its known as is Lower Llanfrechfa. The first bridge built over the Avon was made of wood and was frequently damaged by floods. The present bridge was made of stone and was built in 1800.
